p: Polysaccharides constitute an abundant group of macromolecules present in fungal cell walls. Due to their wide structural variability, they have been shown to have great potential to be biological response modifiers (BRMs). The composition of monosaccharide residues, including their sequence and placement as well as their connections and position of glycosidic linkages, affect polysaccharide activities [ 1]. One of the mushroom polysaccharides—chitin—is a water-insoluble and indigestible compound in the human gastrointestinal tract acting as dietary fiber [ 2]. In turn, most polysaccharides present in mushrooms are water-soluble glucans with different types of glycosidic linkages, e.g., (1→3)-α-glucans and (1→3), (1→6)-β-glucans [ 3].
